ratings.comment: Prof. Stambach is caring and dedicated. She knows her subject inside and out. Even if you are not a cultural anthropology major, you will get a lot out of this class. Recommend it highly.

I taught myself this class off the online textbook. Her lectures were boring and never had anything to do with the tests. The tests were all on Canvas and 100% based on the online textbook activities. The discussion was cool, and I had a great TA, but you can get an A in this class without ever going to lecture.

This class was very boring but an easy A. Lectures are not required and all exams, quizzes, and even the final were online on your own time, and open note. There was a lot of busywork involved for discussions... the assignments were pretty easy but took up a lot of time outside of class just because of how long they were.

Lectures are very slow and boring, but easily skippable if you read the textbook (1 chapter per week) and take mediocre notes. Tests are online (2 attempts each). Workload is pretty significant (3 major projects, 3 reading responses), only because there is a lot of busy work. Expect to write 1000-1500 words per assignment.

Had tech issues every lecture, and relied on TAs to fix it. Boring lectures, and super skippable classes so that is a bonus. However, assignments didn't have much to do with lecture and assigned a lot of busy work that took forever and was not worth many points.
Very easy to skip... She is clearly enthusiastic about Anthropology but if you aren't then the class is a bore.

Amy is an amazing professor! Her lectures are very interesting, she is a delight to talk to and learn from in the class and after the lectures as well. She knows a lot of stuff and can make you think in ways you never thought to think of before. Definitely a powerhouse in anthropology!! I am inclined to take more classes in Anthro because of her.

Although I only took this course for credits for my major, I found the teacher to be passionate about the subject. Her enthusiasm towards anthropology made lectures much better compared to some classes where the teachers are quiet and monotone. Overall, I enjoyed this professor because she was nice and you could tell she loved what she was teaching

I really liked Anthropology, so it wasn't as boring as it could be.  However, she had technical difficulties almost every lecture, would go off topic several times, and droned on about Africa when it wasn't on the test.  She was also gone once, and her TA had a more interesting lecture than she could ever give.
I really like her lectures and she is very passionate about what she is talking about. If you show up and do the work, it is pretty easy to get a good grade. All exams are online which is nice.

I asked help for with the discussion question in person for both TA Andrea and Amy. Avoid ANDREA and AMY. These people are terrible.

Their attitudes were very disrespectful and not helpful. 

I should have dropped this course, seriously. Just one discussion project messed up, and the entire grade so.

Professor Stambach seems intimidating at first but I really grew to like her and her class. She cares about her students and really wants you to learn through real life examples. 477 is heavily discussion and reading based but the workload was never overwhelming. I would recommend taking a class with her!

Dr. Stambach has boring lectures, but she is really passionate about what she does. She will try and scary you in the beginning, but if you show up to class and do the work you are guaranteed to get a good grade.

Professor Stambach realizes the potential of her students. She thoroughly covers the topics, and she also has great fashion sense! The class itself was very easy; all the exams are online, and you basically just have to show up to lecture and take notes to pass. I would highly recommend for an easy class.

I love Amy!! She is so sweet and a wonderful professor. She should either have more material or shorter lectures since she only needs to cover about 5 slides of information per class. She comes to class happy and always finds other things to tie into our units. She teaches us new things and always makes sure to use her voice for the greater good!

Prof. Stambach is such a passionate professor! She will talk about sensitive issues and if you care enough, you will start thinking about what you can do, as a person for the world to be a better place. It is an easy A class but how much you get from the class comes down to how willing you are to learn these difficult/sensitive issues.

Yes the class is easy and I will admit the lectures can feel long since Amy has very little material to cover. However, she has a strong passion for what she talks about and always does her best to be inclusive. She really thinks about her words and how they can be taken. Super nice and kinda funny when she runs around the stage. I enjoyed her!

Amy is SO passionate about what she does and cares deeply about everything that she discusses. She loves discussion & loves hearing what her students have to say. Although this class is not my speciality nor in my area of interest, I still was able to develop a deeper respect for the topics discussed in class.
One of the most passionate professors Ive had! An amazing anthropologist and teacher!

Yes, this class is an easy A. However, thats because of the format decided by the whole anthro department. Professor Stambach really cares about her class, her research, and being inclusive. She is inspiring and manages to engage everyone even in a big lecture setting. I really respect her as an anthropologist and teacher.
The class was really engaging and the coursework was not too hard. The extra bits of information that Professor Stambach adds into her lecture is something I always look forward to.

I don't know why so many people here hate her, she's a passionate professor who is knowledgeable and eager to share her work. I enjoyed classes and found them interesting. If you aren't interested in anthropology just don't take this class, I feel like that's common sense.

Amy is ok. Easy class, but lectures bore me. If I were interested in Anthropology it might have been a little better. She talks a lot about herself and Africa. Not the best professor I have had, but it was fine.

i would say her lectures are boring, but I didn't go to class.I still managed to get a 100 in the class. REALLY boring. If you care about anthro/want to major in it, my friends in 105 love it and think it is really interesting. You can put 0 effort into this class, and just get a GPA boost. Plus it's an ethnic studies credit!
The lectures are not interesting, but you don't need to go to get 100% on the exams. Good for bringing gpa up but not a great class overall.

Amy is the worst. I mean, she isn't bad, but just really boring and only talks about her time in Africa. Only plus was she played music in the beginning of lecture. I stopped going to lecture, however I found out later she was starting to use specific examples from lecture in exams. Long story short, ended up going towards end of semester.

Eh, I wouldn't stress too much if I had her as my professor. The lectures are unnecessary, so just do the InQuizitive and go to discussion, and you'll get an A. (I did.) If you can, take the exams as groups with your friends or other students.

Prof Stambach is, simply put, an awful professor. Her lectures go off on random tangents and she makes constant factual errors while lecturing. Nothing in lecture actually connects well to the textbook/discussion. She also brags about her research experience in exams - like really? You only need to put work into the book review and nothing else.

Honestly I went to lecture maybe twice and realized that they're useless-- the whole lecture is either something totally off topic or going over stuff we've read. The only homework was inquisitive and fieldwork assignments which were easy to bs. TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU NEED CREDIT!!!! SO EASY SERIOUSLY DO IT THE EXAMS ARE EVEN ONLINE

Stupidly easy class, online exams, lectures are pointless and all that matters is that you go to discussion and read the text and you get an A. Amy herself was not very bright, one day in class she said "...a pound of milk-or whatever a unit of milk is." (A gallon?) Need I say more?

Sometimes I lie awake at night, wondering if this ANTHRO104 class is even real. In all my years on this planet, I have never taken a course this incredibly easy. You don't have to ever go to lecture. The exams are online for heaven's sake. Don't delay. Take this class if you need credit. A WHOLE LECTURE WAS LITERALLY SOME GIRL GETTING ACUPUNCTURE.

This is the easiest class I have taken at UW Madison. Do not have to go to lecture, but should go to some discussions for participation credit. All answers to exams are on Quizlet. Not sure why many people think this class requires a lot of work, it requires almost none. Maybe a paragraph per week for fieldwork journals. Amy doesn't contribute much

I took this course to fulfill my ethics credits. Less than stellar professor. She goes off on tangents during lecture. Not only do they have no direction, they correlate little to none with the discussions. Easy class, but not worth the time of going to lecture hoping to gain anything. Would not recommend if you want a meaningful class.
It was super easy, but it wasn't even necessary to attend Lecture. Both exams are online and grading is easy. I enjoyed Prof. Stambach but the lectures didn't really complement the discussions.

Stambach's lectures are like nails on a chalkboard. She is super boring, barely covers any material in class, and is just overall awful. Luckily, she doesn't take attendance, so you can skip lecture as long as you show up to discussion once a week.
Basically she goes off on random tangents and puts these on the exam. She teaches lecture like a big discussion. I learned nothing from this class
I have no personal reservations with professor Amy, her work in anthropology is in no doubt venerable. The course itself is interesting, but the lectures do not compliment it well

Look, yes this class was interesting and not difficult. That aspect was great. But, I really did not like professor Stambach. At first I liked her and then I got sick of her talking about herself instead of us learning valuable information. She also made an insensitive comment about drug addiction and I've thought less of her since.

This class was not hard, but also very interesting. Her lectures were definitely not necessary to go to (if you read the textbook), but were still enjoyable. I highly recommend this class for people trying to get the requirement out of the way painlessly.

Other people posting here have a ax to grind. Maybe they did worse that they said they did and just feel salty. Prof. Stambach is definitely smart and makes sense in class. If you cant pay attention for more than 30 sec then that's your fault. She tells good stories too
The previous ratings regarding Prof Stambach are overly harsh-- she was an enthusiastic professor with a clear passion for her field. Good introductory course, not too difficult.
Easiest A ever. Went to 2 lectures total, passed just fine. Do your textbook readings and quizzes, show up to discussion, you'll pass easily.

I stop going to lectures after the third one. Managed an A. Class is an absolute joke. Do the online stuff and youll get an A. Spend your time wisely and dont go to lecture, but you have to go to discussion.

Lectures rarely got through more than 2 slides at a max. Not good for notes. Amy would talk so long about topics that you would lose the point 15 minutes into her comment on an irrelevant rant. Read the textbook and complete the Inquizitive homework to get an A. Lectures are pointless. Discussions require at least 2 comments each class to get an A.

During maybe the second lecture of the semester she told a story about how she was once pulled over by a cop on her way to work, got out of the car, told the guy I dont have time for this and ran off. I never attended lecture again. Got an A.

Easiest A ever, professor reads direct quotes and definitions from textbook for her lectures. I did not show up to lecture for 5 weeks and did not read the textbook and had no trouble on the final exam.

I honestly don't know how Amy is allowed to teach a class. Lectures were literally her reading from the book and talking about her fieldwork that barely related to course content. Randomly missed 2 weeks of class to travel and we had to listen to guest lecturers. She brought nothing of value to the class; least favorite UW professor I've had.

The lectures were extremely dull. I can't even remember how many, but she missed maybe 5 lectures and had other people come in. She talked a ton about her fieldwork, probably more than most people care about. She seems nice but the lectures are just so dull that it's hard to care about the topic. Super easy class though.

She was fine. Definitely not the best professor in the world, but her class was easy. Lectures are really boring and you don't need to go. The notes she presents are just definitions. There are 2 midterms, both online, and a final book review. She was gone for two weeks, which was annoying, but not a big deal because you're better off just reading
i wish i could give a negative rating

Amy's lecture material is basically reading definitions out of the book and talking about her personal life. You'd be better off skipping lectures and just reading the textbook. I skipped lecture from the third week on and got an A. I would not recommend taking any courses taught by Amy, even if you're interested in the material.

I had Amy for an introductory course and she was absolutely awful. She was extremely disorganized and unprofessional. She also prevents incorrect information constantly. This is a direct quote from lecture "The KKK was founded in 1966 during the civil war" she never corrected herself. The class itself was easy but she made it a terrible time.

She spends more time in classes bragging about her fieldwork and calling kids out who sit in the back than actually lecturing. I haven't gone to lecture since the second week of school and got a 97% on the midterm. Actually going is absolutely a waste of time and I learn more from reading the book in bed.
